flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction:
Aim

The aim of this project is to develop an open source framework and plans for electricity generation. Open source means, that the plans will be accessible by anyone, and that it is allowed to distribute and modify them.

The framework feeds on multiple renewable resources, and channels them into the electric systems through various modules: Solar panels, solar collectors, biogas digesters, steam engines and micro-hydro turbines.

Upon my visit to Nepal, the framework then can be adapted to local conditions. If there is a lot of water in the streams, micro-hydro makes sense. If there is clear sun, solarfire would be the favorite choice.

Above all, these technologies should be locally assembled and maintainable. To find out more about each module, visit the framework-page.

In order to do the research, some funding for materials will be needed. Visit the funding and budget page, or see an overview below.

Current Funding

This funding campaign has two phases. Phase one will ensure enough funds for building a methane digester and composting toilets, which are very low cost. If funding covers phase two, then either SolarFire technology, or a microhydro system will be built, depending on the local situation at Maya Universe Academy. Please consider donating!

Upon my arrival, I will do a thorough site assessment, in order to decide which modules of the framework to build. See the timeline below or find out more on the timeline-page.

Background

This is my senior project at the College of the Atlantic. Over the past 3 years, I have been focusing my studies around the topic of social, economic and environmental sustainability, drawing links between ecological and economic systems and focusing on the paradigm of local production, global collaboration. The basis of such economic systems are building plans -- information -- that is held and developed in common, while production from these plans happens within localized markets. This kind of movement is called the open source hardware movement, following the open source phenomenon as seen with both software and content: Both code and content can be in written form, hence people can collaborate on them easily. The open source software movement gave rise to Firefox and Linux, the open hardware movement is about to give rise to the technologies communities need to sustain themselves in terms of production of technological goods and energy.

The open source hardware projects focus on technology that can be locally assembled and maintained, are modular and last a lifetime. The Open Source Ecology project for example is developing 50 technologies that moden civilzations needs to live comfortable. Included in the set are agricultural machinery including a tractor with a modular power unit that can be used to power the other machines, such as a earth brick press.

Some of these open technologies focus on energy production. Solar fire, wireless, phones

guide.summary: I have developed an open source framework for electricity generation that can be adapted to local conditions. I plan to raise 6400 in order to build part of the framework at Maya Universe Academy which provides free primary-school education in rural Nepal
guide.title: OpenPower Nepal
